odds.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: difficulties which make a good result seem very unlikely
odds.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The hospital’s director has been battling against the odds to improve patient care.
The soldiers’ job was to hold on despite impossible odds.
odds.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the numbers that show how much money you will win if you bet on the winner of a horse race or other competition
odds.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Everyone was surprised when Desert Zone won the race, at very long odds.
They are laying odds of 8–1 that the Conservatives will win the next election.
At odds of 10–1 he bet a hundred pounds.
odds.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 2: difficulties which make a good result seem very unlikely
odds.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: He survived a night in the cold water against incredible odds.
We must hope that, despite great odds, we can achieve a peaceful settlement.
They face impossible odds simply trying to get an education.
They face overwhelming odds in their struggle to preserve the park.
The baby, born sixteen weeks too early, defied the odds and is celebrating her first birthday.
The Coastguard was battling against the odds to keep the oil spill from reaching the shore.
Against all odds, he recovered from his illness.
the odds are stacked against somebody
They may be able to build a life for themselves, but the odds are stacked against them.
odds.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: how likely it is that something will happen
odds.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The odds of us achieving our sales targets are very poor.
The odds are  (=it is likely that) selling will continue.
odds.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: difficulties that make a good result seem very unlikely
odds.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The small company overcame enormous odds to become a success.
Successful entrepreneurs have a will to succeed against all odds (=even when there are great difficulties).
odds.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: if two people or groups are at odds, they disagree about something or they often disagree about things
odds.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The head cook and head porter are constantly at odds.
odds.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: if two statements, descriptions, actions etc are at odds with each other, they are different although they should be the same
odds.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Sometimes trade union negotiators set targets which are at odds with the targets set by management.
odds.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: to pay or charge a higher price than is usual or reasonable
odds.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Are supermarket customers paying over the odds for fruit and vegetables?
